activity-description.narrative: Enhancing Climate Resilience of the Vulnerable Communities and Ecosystems in Somalia.

description.narrative: Number of Land Use Policies and implementation roadmaps developed that support sustainable Natural Resources Management

comment.narrative: Land use policies and proper enforcement mechanisms on land-use do not exist in all zones of Somalia. This has led to conflicts over natural resources and exacerbated tensions between grazing nomadic pastoralists and sedentary agro-pastoralists. Rural populations are also using land in an ad-hoc manner, cutting trees to produce charcoal and encroaching on grazing lands.

1. One Land Use Policy for at least one zone developed. 2. A gender-sensitive climate compatible National Development Plan (2017-19) finalised 3. At least 300 women trained in adaptation technologies as a foundation for starting sustainable technology marketing enterprises 4. One Project board meeting held.

1. At the national level, Somalia is covered under Regional Climate Change Strategy for the member states of Intergovernmental Agency for Development (IGAD) with support from the UNDP/GEF/LDCF Project. IGAD Regional Climate Change Strategy sets the framework for the National Climate Change Policy for Somalia being formulated by the UNDP/GEF/LDCF Project. The national land policy draft finalized in Somaliland and its review at regional and district level completed. Puntland Land Policy formulation is still ongoing with MoEWT. 2. National Disaster Management Policy to be initiated after the formulation of National Climate Change Policy which is currently under initiation stage and anticipation is to have it completed by the end of 2017. In addition, 2 existing disaster management policies (Somaliland and Puntland) have been updated while the one for South Central to be part of 2017 LOA with Somali Disaster Management Agency (SoDMA)
3.A total of 280 women (160-Somaliland and 120-Puntland) have been trained on adaptation technologies and benefited upscaling activities i.e. fodder production, reforestation -water harvesting .and small scale business cooperatives.
4. Two project Board Meeting were conducted in October and December 2016 with participants from the Federal Government and regional member States key sector ministries. Key Decisions from the meetings were as follows: a. Project Board Meeting -28th October 2016: â€¢ Quarterly Progress Report for the quarter ending 30 September 2016 to be shared with participants of the Project Board Meeting â€¢ Mid-term evaluation of the project should focus on whether the investments under this project have brought positive changes to the lives of the people â€¢ The impacts of the training and policies should be assessed and any recommendations for future improvements should help in revising the project logic â€¢ Project should also look into possibilities of expanding the focus according to new administrative realities in Somali

1. Land Use Policy for at least one zone developed. 2. National Disaster Management Policy developed and at least 2 existing plans/policies are updated to address climate risks. 3. National climate change policy is developed including a fund mobilization strategy to raise public and private financing earmarked for climate change adaptation in all zones. 4. A gender-sensitive climate compatible National Development Plan (2017-19) finalised 5. Design and construction of two 50,000 m3 earth dams in Puntland and Somaliland, rehabilitation of 4 dams in South Central, 6, 5 and 8 water diversions constructed in Puntland, Somaliland and South Central respectively, rehabilitation of 4 canals in South Central and rehabilitation of 4 boreholes in South Central 6. At least 200 ha of forest reforested. 7. 8 Agro-Pastoral Field Schools (APFS) established (2 in each district) with 200 direct beneficiaries per APFS (30% women) 8. One (1) gender-sensitive plan developed by each District Disaster Management Committee to be created (with women representation) in the eight target districts (8 plans total) 9. At least 100 women in the four target districts in Southern Central Regions (Guriel, Balanbale, Afgoye, and Jowhar) trained in adaptation technologies as a foundation for starting sustainable technology marketing enterprises

1. Somaliland Land Use Policy completed. 2. National Disaster Management Policy was developed and finalised by Somalia Disaster Management Agency (SODMA). In Somaliland, A disaster management strategy was developed for NERAD while HADMA of Puntland has finalised its disaster management strategy. 3. 60% of the National Climate Change Policy Draft is completed. Also, the Somalia Climate Change Report with loss and Damage, and Adaptation Finance Instruments Chapters have been finalised. 4. Accomplished in previous quarter 5. Somaliland: 95% completion for the Construction work of the 2 earth dams (50,000m3) at Eil-Afweyn and Baligubadle districts. With good rainfall season, over 6000HHs in the 2 districts and surrounding villages will benefit from earth dam infrastructures 90% completion for 70 Berkads rehabilitation. The traditional water reservious will improve the access of a clean water for nearly 16,000HHs (3000HHs-Haaji Salah, 400HHs-Durugsi, 2500HHs-Balidhiig, and 6000HHs-Sanaag drought affected HHs), additionally 4 water diversions competed, and 4 are ongoing. Puntland: construction of 3 new water diversions completed and 4 ongoing. Also, Feasibility studies for 4 earth dams and selection of 14 berkeds rehabilitation were achieved, BOQ, and detail Designs completed, and reviewed by UNDP. South Central: The project has handed over 5 infrastructure sites in two districts (Jowhar-Hir-Shabelle, and Afgooye-South West States) on 26th August 2017, Whereas, 4 sites in Balanbale and Guriel districts are pending for hand over due to suspension from Ministry of Environment of Galmudug state. overall progress, 2 canals in Jowhar (Kafunji, and Bukurale) and Kafunji Water catchments were completed, while Afgooye canal (Irdoole) and Water catchment (Irdoole) are at finalisation stage. 6. Puntland: Afforestation and reseeding of 70 ha in Libaho and Salama villages under Dangorayo district are on-going. Central Somalia: Project has considered other options to implement

comment.narrative:
Output 1: 1.1: Nine reconciliation conferences/meetings have been held in ISWA, GIA and Hiraan/Middle Shabelle (18% women participants at conferences held in Q1 2016)
Output 2: 2.1: Two technical officers (2M) and three interns (2M:1W) provided to support the BFC (together with short-term international consultants: 1M:1W) 2.3: A work plan for the federalization sub-committee of the BFC has been prepared and vision for BFC drafted 2.4: Five technical advisors/officers (4M:1W) and 10 interns (9M:1W) provided to MoIFA; No technical advisors/officers/ interns have been provided to OPM. Weak existing capacity, as evidenced by a recent Government Institutions Capacity Assessment (GICA) conducted by USAID/ Chemonics in November 2014 of MoIFA
Output 3: 3.2: Emerging state institutions are new and, therefore, lack infrastructure. Some social infrastructure delivered in districts, though none as federal member state infrastructure
Output 4: 4.1: One baseline assessment completed in ISWA; Jubbaland baseline assessment was initiated but not completed 4.2: Total of six technical advisors/officers (2 at ISWA, 3 at GIA and 1 at JSS; 0% women) and 30 interns (10 at each FMS) in place at emerging state administrations (23M:7W)
Output 5: 5.4: State planning process initiated in April 2016 for ISWA and GIA; no public engagement as of yet

STEFS ANNUAL (Q4) 2016 RESULTS: Output 1: a) Hirshabelle interim Administration in Q4 2016, and drafted a charter for the HirShabelle interim administration. b) Four (4) mediation processes supported, facilitated and led by FMSFGS in Merka, Balanbale, Gedo and Galkayo between April and December 2016 (with 26% women representation) c) 22% with 35% Women of state administration staff; (77. 45%with 20.33% Women of GSS staff; 15.26% with 55.38% Women of JSS staff; and 8% with 58.92% Women of SWS staff) were trained in conflict management and community problem solving d) One (1) inclusive consultations undertaken between Jubbaland State of Somalia and diasporas on federalism and federal state endorsement criteria (with 20% women representation) e) 182 community members/leaders and other citizens were trained in conflict management and community problem solving (with 20% women representation)

comment.narrative: 1. 768 (M: 610 W:158) MPs and Staff trained on legislative drafting, principles of democracy and democratic society, RoP, public outreach etc. 2. Video and Teleconference equipment provided to NFP and Puntland to improve communication. 3. Construction of security perimeter walls for NFP, Puntland and Somaliland HoRs completed. 4. Development of Somaliland House of Elders (Guurti) Strategic Plan 2016-2021. 5. NFP has completed follow up of ABRIMO recommendations of the third party assessment. 6. The project produced a Parliamentary Regional Offices Manual for Somaliland parliament. 7. NFP legal archiving has been upgraded. 8. Southwest State Assembly received sound system equipment to support parliamentary members to conduct debates effectively.

1. Committees supported to provide oversight of laws and policy. 2. 2 members of Parliamentary leadership supported to develop agendas, order of business, etc. 3. At least 3 activities from communication strategy implemented

1. Capacity of the new MPs 55 (M 53, W 2) from Hirshabelle State Assembly improved, as they are now familiar with the parliamentary practices to perform their constitutional duties including oversight of laws and policy. 2. 2 members of Parliamentary leadership supported to develop agendas, order of business, etc. 3. Parliamentary websites serve as important ways for citizens to learn about their parliament, access to legislation records and communicate with their local MPs. In that regard, UNDP Parliamentary Support Project supported the emerging states to develop websites. So far, Galmudug State Assembly went live last year and Jubaland State Assembly official website went online in February 2017 and it can be accessed at. http://www.jubbalandstateassembly.so/. The other state assemblies are set to go online in Quarter 2.

description.narrative: 2016 1)The extent to which the NIEC's institutional capacity is developed 2) Number of inclusive stakeholder engagement and public outreach programmes planned and implemented, including gender mainstreaming

comment.narrative: The 20122 Federal Parliament was selected through a political process by 135 designated clan Elders. No electoral capacity in place at the Federal Level in Somalia before 2015. (No Electoral Law, NIEC Law approved in Feb 2015; NIEC established in July 2015)

1) An electoral process is held for the election of a new Federal Parliament. 2) The legal framework for universal elections is being developed 3) Institutional capacity of the NIEC is being developed
Quarter 3 2016 1) The NIEC is operational and initial institutional capacity in place 2) Public is informed and stakeholders are engaged in the 2016 process according to plan

1) Key support included developing guiding principles and possible measures to ensure and enhance transparency, minimum quota for female representation in both houses, support to draft codes of conduct, as well as projections with regard to logistical and budgetary requirements. The Electoral Support Joint Programme further assisted the FIEIT with the planning of the electoral budget and funding discussions with donor partners. Together with senior representatives of UNSOM and UNDP, discussions were held at the highest level of the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) on the budget, the Governmentâ€™s contribution, and the financial mechanism to collect and manage the candidatesâ€™ registration fees. 2) As part of the 2020 Roadmap regarding the preparation of universal elections, the Joint Programme has been discussing with the NIEC and MOIFA how to initiate the first conceptual steps towards the development of the Electoral Law in an inclusive and consultative manner. To facilitate research that will inform the development of a draft Electoral Law, the Joint Programme supported the compilation of a â€œCompendium of Electoral Legislation of Somalia (1953-1969)â€ comprising 12 laws in English, including 6 translated from Italian into English, which has been shared with MOIFA. Translation of the Compendium into Somali has commenced to be completed in the next quarter. 3) Strengthening the foundation of the preparations for the 2020 elections, the NIEC recruited in July an â€˜actingâ€™ Secretary-General (Chief Electoral Officer), together with the first phase of its Secretariat staff, including national advisors supported by the Joint Programme. In this respect, the Joint Programme provided in August a finance training for the newly recruited NIEC Operations staff, to strengthen their understanding of procurement processes, finance and assets management. The Joint Programme also conducted a session focusing on a capacity development plan for the Secretariat. On 15 August, the Joi

1. The NIEC is operational and initial institutional capacity in place 2. MOIFA takes the lead in coordinating the development of the electoral law 3. Review of the Political Party Law and on the formulation of the electoral lexicon 4. Lexicon is finalized 5. Electoral process concluded as planned and lead to the establishment of a new Federal Parliament

- NIEC institutional capacity improved and functional. long-term technical capacity of Somaliaâ€™s National Independent Electoral Commission (NIEC) developed. - On 26 August, MOIFAR organized a coordination session on the drafting process of the Electoral Law with key partners from the federal government, including the NIEC, representatives from the Office of the President as well as of the Prime Minister, a Member of the Parliament, MOCA, MOWAHR, and MOJ. - The lexicon has been finalized and is being printed for wider distribution. - Electoral process concluded as scheduled and the 10th Federal Parliament established

â€¢ Value chain development analysis of: (a) fishery, (b) dry fish export, (c) dairy, (d) sesame, completed; and the reports, with recommendations, developed â€¢ Along the fish value chain, 5 dry fish processing facilities constructed in Bossaso â€¢ 30 youth trained in fish production, processing, packaging and marketing, and engaged in dry fish businesses and made the constructed 5 dry fish processing facilities functional in Bossaso â€¢ The Gaâ€™ate and Bulsho gravel roads (690m) that connects to the dry fish processing centres to markets, rehabilitated; and 150 youth got short term- job opportunity in Bosasso. â€¢ 1,440 short-term employments created for the drought-affected people (1,061 women) in both Somaliland and South West State â€¢ In response to drought, 3 water catchments, with a total capacity of 12,300 cubic m., built/rehabilitated, that benefitted 306 residents (50% women and girls) in 3 villages of Somaliland, who lost their livestock due to drought. â€¢ 985 short-term jobs created by improving sanitary condition of 51 new IDP camps in Baidoa. â€¢ 300 short-term jobs created (over 100 women) for debris cleaning in the aftermath of the devastated explosion in Mogadishu â€¢ 600 short-term jobs created (over 200 women) during the rehabilitation of public infrastructure in Mogadishu. â€¢ Two Programme Steering Committee meetings held in March and September 2017. 11 media stories and columns (against the target of 7) were published and featured on Geeska Africa Newsletter and several websites.
This target has also been fully met. 49 (27 from SL & 25 PL) young women recipients of UNDP GEWE tertiary scholarship have successfully completed their undergraduate programme.

1. Women Empowerment policy adopted in Puntland 2. Revised Provisional Federal Constitution includes gender perspectives. 3. GBV/Sexual offense laws are enacted in SL and FL 4. CEDAW ratification process reactivated

National Gender Policy for FGS. GEWE has approved agreement with the MWHRD and hired Gender advisor to support national consultations. In PL, women empowerment policy is being translated into Somali language.
A series of political changes following the election of new government in this quarter delayed the Review of the Provisional Federal Constitution. However, the process of nominating MPs to the constitutional oversight committee is ongoing Sexual Offence bill was approved in PL by the standing committee of parliament in this reporting period. SOB in SL has been tabled to the parliament for discussion and approval. FL SOB is being publicly consulted

title.narrative: Constitutional Review Support_Approved PIP - Project Document

description.narrative: Roadmap and MoU signed among three key role players MOCA, ICRIC and Parliamentary Oversight Committee (OC) defines the guiding principles for the constitutional review process, namely a fixed timeline, Somali ownership, continuation and recognition of the work done by the 9th parliament, inclusivity, transparency, participation, accountability as well as partnership and cooperation. This support UNDP programme envisages to assist the key stakeholders in upholding these principles while carrying out their respective mandates.
